[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures may impede readability despite grammatical correctness.

[STRUCTURE]: Dense paragraphs slightly disrupt pacing, though logical flow is maintained.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "The fate of what the world...")
[LEXICON]: Occasionally awkward phrasing (e.g., "disengage such physical and material well-being")

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from materialism’s critique to consumer culture’s effects
[STRUCTURE]: Dense, paragraph-long arguments without clear internal transitions

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures may impede readability.

[TRANSITION]: Some paragraph jumps (e.g., from "moral choices" to "global integration") could benefit from clearer linking.

[LEXICON]: Overly complex vocabulary and sentence structures may impede smooth readability for non-specialized readers.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, lengthy sentences require careful parsing.

[STRUCTURE]: Paragraphs are densely packed with abstract concepts, risking overwhelming the reader.
[TRANSITION]: Subtle connections between critiques of religious conceptions and Bahá'í teachings could be more explicitly signaled.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally overly complex, lengthy sentences may impede immediate clarity.

[TRANSITION]: Minimal abruptness between thematic shifts (e.g., from cultural evolution to clerical influence), though logically coherent overall.

[LEXICON]: Overly formal vocabulary and complex sentence structures may impede readability for non-specialist readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between paragraphs discussing different scriptural examples (e.g., Bible to Bhagavad-Gita).
[STRUCTURE]: Assumes extensive prior knowledge of religious texts, potentially disrupting coherence for unfamiliar readers.

[LEXICON]: Overly complex vocabulary and phrasing (e.g., "intractable historical circumstances," "draconian rule") may hinder readability for non-specialist audiences.
[SYNTAX]: Frequent use of long, nested sentences (e.g., "While the monotheistic beliefs...") slows flow.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between historical examples (e.g., Hebrews, Muslims) and modern societal critiques (e.g., crime/punishment, slavery).
[STRUCTURE]: Repetitive emphasis on "religion’s role in its time" without clear thematic bridging between paragraphs.

[LEXICON]: Occasionally complex sentence structures may slightly impede readability for non-specialist audiences.

[STRUCTURE]: Mildly abrupt transition between chapters, though thematic consistency is maintained.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures may impede readability despite grammatical correctness.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between discussing evil, unity, and covenant-breaking without explicit connective tissue.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, dense sentence structures (e.g., "the obligation of the Bahá'í community...").
[LEXICON]: Occasionally awkward phrasing (e.g., "never-ending continuum of spiritual search").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from individual spiritual responsibility to historical consciousness ("One of the distinguishing features of modernity...").
[STRUCTURE]: Ideas (e.g., interfaith vs. Bahá'í mission) could be more explicitly connected to preceding paragraphs.
